Situation1: They fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription where even a small error could have severe consequences for the patient.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: The prescription in my hand trembled as I read the oncologist’s instructions for a potent chemotherapy drug. Every decimal, every milligram, had to be perfect—one slip could mean disaster for the patient. My mind raced through the calculations, double-checking, triple-checking, as the clock ticked closer to noon. That was when I was supposed to meet the mayor and the sisters at the parish hall. The hurricane had left so many without shelter, and the mayor pleaded for my help to coordinate the relief effort. As a nun, I was expected to be there, to comfort, to organize, to serve. But as a pharmacist, I couldn’t rush this prescription. The weight of both callings pressed on my chest. I could hear the anxious voices of the sisters in my mind, urging me to hurry, while the silent, desperate hope of the patient’s family echoed from the prescription label. My hands hovered between the medication and my ringing phone, torn by the impossible demands of duty and compassion, knowing that whatever I chose, someone would be left waiting.
